There are a number of known issues on Ubuntu <nowiki>[[PowerPC]]</nowiki>, most of these have simple work-arounds.  This page holds any release specific workarounds.  Remember to also check the troubleshooting and setup guides in the <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki>. 

The general Release Notes are <nowiki>[[http://www.ubuntu.com/getubuntu/releasenotes|here]]</nowiki>.

=== 14.10 Utopic Unicorn ===

==== Radeon users ====

The legacy radeon framebuffer (radeonfb) is nolonger built-in to the kernel, but is now compiled as a module - see <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/1377878|bug]]</nowiki>.  This means KMS is on and active from the go!

Like previous versions, some systems will need the yaboot parameter radeon.agpmode=-1 to circumvent freezes (so far this is confirmed for Radeon 9200 chips in AGP based G4 iBook's). You will need to set that yaboot parameter again after an installation as that will not carry over from the booted ISO - see <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_make_a_yaboot_parameter_permanent.3F|FAQ]]</nowiki> for how to do this.

==== Sound does not work on some machines ====

Please confirm the hw-detect <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/hw-detect/+bug/1296373|bug]]</nowiki> ('''see comments #10 and #14''').  

A fix for the !PowerBook6,5 using <nowiki>[[https://help.ubuntu.com/community/DKMS|DKMS]]</nowiki> can be found <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2209340&page=7&p=13173354#post13173354|here]]</nowiki> and a more generic fix is <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2209340&page=10&p=13328573#post13328573|here]]</nowiki>.

==== Radeon users ====

Please read the advice for 12.10 and 12.04 below. It is recommended to use a yaboot parameter such as video=radeonfb:1024x768-32 with the live/desktop iso (see <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#What_yaboot_parameters_should_I_use_for_graphics_problems.3F|FAQ]]</nowiki> for more details). After the install you can switch to using KMS which could give better performance (hibernate can be used instead of suspend).

The yaboot parameter video=ofonly will activate KMS, but this will likely need to also be combined with radeon.agpmode=-1 to stop freezes/crashes.

==== Power Mac G5 ====

Set of fixes for various issues on the Power Mac G5. Might work in other Macs as well.

'''Wireless'''

Use ''sudo apt-get install firmware-b43-installer''

You can then reboot or use
 
 ''sudo modprobe â€“r b43

 sudo modprobe b43''

''' !WiFi Hotspot (Access Point Mode)'''

See this <nowiki>[[http://askubuntu.com/questions/180733/how-to-setup-an-access-point-mode-wi-fi-hotspot/439530#439530|post]]</nowiki>.

'''Sound'''

Add ''snd-aoa-i2sbus'' to ''/etc/modules'' file. You can then reboot or use modprobe. 

'''2D Acceleration Under Nvidia Cards'''

Using ''nouveau.noaccel=1'' will fix graphical issues but will disable all hardware acceleration, making for slow videos etc. A possible fix has been found to get working 2D acceleration:

Nouveau driver has issues with MSI interrupts, use yaboot parameter 
 ''nouveau.config=NvMSI=0''

You can also add it to your ''/etc/yaboot.conf'' and update using ''sudo ybin -v'' (see the <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_make_a_yaboot_parameter_permanent.3F|FAQ]]</nowiki> for more info)

Create this file ''/etc/initramfs-tools/conf.d/splash''
add this line exactly:
 ''FRAMEBUFFER=y''

Run ''sudo update-initramfs -u''

More info <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2292210&p=13347607#post13347607|here]]</nowiki>.

Although using this method has been confirmed working with an Nvidia 6600, there have been occasional reported glitches. YMMV, depending on individual hardware etc. Feedback is appreciated.

Another possible option is to use the old nv driver, which has been recompiled.  See this <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2294789|thread]]</nowiki> for details. You may have to downgrade xorg.

==== "Fixing recursive fault but reboot is needed!" ====

See <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/1066435|bug]]</nowiki>.  Try booting with the parameter:

snd-powermac.blacklist=yes
</pre>
==== Radeon Userspace Mode Setting (UMS) removed ====

You now have to use KMS with the radeon xorg driver. If you don't you'll fallback into 8 bit pseudo colour with the fbdev driver (see <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/1040526|bug]]</nowiki>). The 8 bit depth will stop ubiquity (the live/desktop installer) working (<nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ubiquity/+bug/1040544|bug]]</nowiki>).

If you need suspend then you'll have to use the fbdev driver, but you'll want to increase the default colour depth via a yaboot parameter (for example, video=radeonfb:1024x768-32) or an xorg.conf:
<pre>
Section "Screen"
  Identifier "Screen0"
  DefaultDepth  24
EndSection
</pre>

You may need to define an xorg.conf to use radeon KMS. See <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/xserver-xorg-video-ati/+bug/1058641|bug]]</nowiki> report.

=== 12.04 Precise Pangolin ===
==== iMac G3 ====
See <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2131612|this]]</nowiki> thread.

==== iMac G4 700/800 or other nVidia users ====
Instructions on how to use the old 'nv' driver can be found <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=2131644|here]]</nowiki>.

==== ATI Rage 128 ====
Users with a Rage 128 graphics card will probably find they boot into a low graphics mode (or a command prompt) with the live CDs (<nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/949288|bug]]</nowiki>).  For this reason, some users may prefer to install from the alternate/mini ISOs.  The mini ISO will download the latest kernel version which contains the fix.

For most users this bug should be fixed when you run the Update Manager.  Some users (e.g. those with a G3 iMac) may also have to create an xorg.conf file setting !HorizSync and !VertRefresh values (see <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_configure_an_xorg.conf_file.3F|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki> or thread linked above). AGP users may also have to force PCI mode.  

If you need to install the latest kernel from a command prompt, then type the following:
<pre>
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install linux-image-powerpc-smp
sudo reboot
</pre>
Use "sudo apt-get dist-upgrade" if you want to upgrade all packages.

If you would like to use the live CDs in full technicolor then there are two solutions to you.  Both require starting the CD in <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_boot_into_single_user_mode.3F|single user mode]]</nowiki>.  You can configure an xorg.conf file setting "UseFBDev" "False" and "!NoInt10" "True".  Instructions to do so are <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_configure_an_xorg.conf_file.3F|here]]</nowiki>.  Once configured, issue the command 
<pre>
sudo start lightdm
</pre>
to start the desktop.  The second solution is to disable the openfirmware framebuffer.  At the yaboot prompt type:
<pre>
live video=offb:off single
</pre>
This will freeze or give you a blank screen.  You will have to judge blind when the machine has finished booting which can be longer than you think.  Type the command (you won't see what you type):
<pre>
modprobe aty128fb
</pre>
Text should now appear on the screen.  You can now start the desktop with the "sudo start lightdm" command.

==== Radeon kernel configuration changed ====

A late kernel change (see <nowiki>[[https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/kernel-team/2012-April/020013.html|kernel-team thread]]</nowiki>) means the kernels with the live/alternate ISOs have a different setup to those installed after you run the Update Manager.  The new kernels will have the radeonfb framebuffer built-in (fixes suspend) and KMS turned on by default.  

Some users may experience garbled consoles until they run the Update Manager.  This may mean when shutting down from the Live ISOs the message to press Enter to power off is not displayed correctly.

Users wishing to use 3D-accelerated KMS should disable the radeonfb framebuffer (although you will loose suspend).  One way of doing this is with the <code>video=ofonly</code> yaboot parameter.  If this causes freezing problems then try adding the yaboot parameter <code>radeon.agpmode=-1</code>.  See the <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#Are_there_any_radeon_tweaks_I_can_do.3F|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki> for more details.

KMS brings a more graphical splash screen although this will likely have messed up colours, see <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/plymouth/+bug/564471|bug]]</nowiki>, but there is probably an endian issue in their too (<nowiki>[[https://lists.debian.org/debian-powerpc/2014/01/msg00015.html|source]]</nowiki>).  Increasing the colour depth can improve things (although not totally fix it).  To test this out on an installed system use something like the following at the yaboot prompt:
<pre>
Linux video=offb:off video=radeonfb:off video=1024x768-32 radeon.agpmode=-1
</pre>

To use 3D-accelerated Userspace Mode Setting (UMS) see below.

==== No userspace mode setting 3d hardware acceleration ====
In 12.04 there is nolonger mesa support for Mach64 and Rage 128 cards or user-space mode setting (non-KMS) with radeon cards.  See <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/mesa/+bug/946677|bug]]</nowiki>.

To solve this you need to install an older 7.11 version of libgl1-mesa-dri from <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/oneiric/+source/mesa|launchpad]]</nowiki> or directly downloading from the ubuntu <nowiki>[[http://ports.ubuntu.com/pool/main/m/mesa/|ports repository]]</nowiki>.  Optionally (for 12.04), if you want your mesa packages to match versions then download the other 7.11 mesa PowerPC deb packages:
<pre>
libgl1-mesa-dri
libgl1-mesa-glx
libglapi-mesa
libglu1-mesa
</pre>
Save them together in a directory.  From a terminal 'cd' into that directory and then issue the command
<pre>
sudo dpkg -i *.deb
</pre>
to install all the deb packages together.

You'll now need to 'pin' the version so that they are not updated when you next use the Update Manager.  The easiest way to do this is through the Synaptic Package Manager.  Select the libgl1-mesa-dri, libgl1-mesa-glx, libglapi-mesa, and libglu1-mesa packages in Synaptic and then in the menu goto Package > Lock Version.

Finally, if you have a radeon card then edit your yaboot.conf file to add the <code>radeon.modeset=0</code> <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_make_a_yaboot_parameter_permanent.3F|yaboot parameter]]</nowiki>.  

See the <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#Configure_graphics|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki> for how to optimize your xorg.conf file. 

If you use kwin and open-gl effects then you may come across <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/xorg-server/+bug/1160903|this]]</nowiki> bug.  Please confirm.

''r128 users can alternatively compile and install the <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/~xorg-edgers/+archive/mesa-legacy/+packages|mesa-legacy]]</nowiki> package.  To make it compile on PowerPC you need to edit the debian/rules file, removing the words "sis" and "unichrome" from the "--with-dri-drivers" line.''

==== b43 (Airport Extreme) hangs at missing firmware ====
Not just a PowerPC issue, but it seems the odd computer with a b43 wireless device hangs at boot.  If the last thing you see is a message about missing firmware this could be your problem.  See the <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/950295|bug report]]</nowiki>.  

A workaround is to pass the b43 an unkown parameter as a kernel argument (in the bug report they use the parameter "blacklist" although you could actually use anything).  The <nowiki>[[http://www.debian.org/releases/stable/powerpc/ch05s03.html.en#module-blacklist|'blacklist' parameter]]</nowiki> is supposedly significant to the debian-installer, although from reports it is likely you will have to use the parameter on both a live and installed system until you download the firmware.  At the yaboot prompt use (for live CD and installed system respectively):
<pre>
live b43.blacklist=yes
Linux b43.blacklist=yes
</pre>
The problem is fixed when you install the firmware.  See the question "<nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#Will_my_wireless_work.3F|Will my wireless work?]]</nowiki>" for how to do this.  To get the wifi working you may have to remove b43 from the list in /etc/modprobe.d/blacklist.local (it may of been automatically added to this file by the installer).

==== Installing to USB ====

If you want to install a proper system onto a USB device in 12.04 then it is likely the automatic configuration of your yaboot bootloader will fail and consequently the system will not automatically boot (see <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/yaboot-installer/+bug/956481|bug]]</nowiki>).  For this reason it is recommended to install versions before 12.10 using the alternate/mini ISOs as they allow the bootloader stage to be skipped (the live ISO in 12.04 will not complete properly unless you patch the yaboot-installer file). 
 

=== 11.10 Oneiric Ocelot ===
==== Mini iso fails to recognize hard drive ====
The mini iso (debian-installer or d-i) is missing the pata_macio module.  If your machine requires this module then you may get some sort of message telling you that your hard drive has not been recognised.  The kernel team are <nowiki>[[https://lists.ubuntu.com/archives/kernel-team/2011-November/017979.html|already aware of this]]</nowiki> and it will be fixed in 12.04.

The easiest solution is to install 11.04 and immediately upgrade.  If you are following the instructions in the <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki> then install 11.04 cli, login and then use the command 
<pre>
sudo do-release-upgrade -d
</pre>
to upgrade. Reboot to make sure it is working correctly with the command 
<pre>
sudo reboot
</pre>
See below if you have a problem on reboot following an upgrade.  When you have the 11.10 command line working you can then install the desktop of your choice as described in the <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki>. 

The quicker solution is to <nowiki>[[http://manpages.ubuntu.com/manpages/oneiric/man8/insmod.8.html|insmod]]</nowiki> the pata_macio.ko file.  Download the correct <nowiki>[[https://launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/3.0.0-12.20/+build/2829182|kernel image]]</nowiki> deb file, open it using archive manager and extract the /lib/modules/3.0.0-12-powerpc/kernel/drivers/ata/pata_macio.ko file.  Save it somewhere that you can acces when running the mini iso.  Drop to a shell, mount where you have stored the file and use the insmod command.

==== Busybox shell after upgrade ====
The same module can cause problems after an upgrade to 11.10.  At the Busybox (intramfs) prompt type the commands:
<pre>
modprobe pata_macio
exit
</pre>
The boot should then hopefully resume. Once you login, you can use these additional commands to make it permanent:
<pre>
echo pata_macio | sudo tee -a /etc/initramfs-tools/modules
sudo update-initramfs -u
</pre>
The above is just a fancy way of adding the word <code>pata_macio</code> to the end of the modules file. You could alternatively type <code>sudo nano /etc/initramfs-tools/modules</code> to open the file and add the word on a new line yourself. You must always run <code>update-initramfs -u</code> for the changes to take effect. Reboot using the command <code>sudo reboot</code> to check that it is working.

This is not solely an Ubuntu problem (for example, there are numerous messages on the Debian PowerPC mailing list about it), but the 11.10 release did come before a hardware detect patch could be included.

If the boot didn't resume with the 'modprobe' command then you may have to perform some additional steps.  The pata_macio module is a new ata controller driver and its use means that hard drives have been renamed from hda to sda.  You may have to adjust your yaboot.conf file accordingly.

At the second yaboot prompt type <code>Linux root=/dev/sda3</code> .  That is assuming you have a standard Ubuntu install on partition 3. If you are dual-booting then you may have linux installed on another partition.  The boot should proceed normally or you may have to modprobe the pata_macio module as described above.

Once booted and logged in, open yaboot.conf with the command: <code>sudo nano /etc/yaboot.conf</code>

Change any references of hda to sda.  When you've made and saved your changes use the command <code>sudo ybin -v</code> to copy it across to the boot partition.  Type <code>man yaboot.conf</code> for an explanation of what it all means.

<nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1861871|This]]</nowiki> thread details the problem more.  Do not use <code>yabootconfig</code> as recommended in the thread, but edit the yaboot.conf file yourself.  Some users may also have to pass an <code>ofboot</code> argument to the <code>ybin</code> command. 

You should also be able to boot using the 11.04 kernel image.  At the second yaboot prompt type <code>old</code> .  This will work until you update your kernel image.

==== Blank screen or flashing question mark after running ybin ====
This occurs because ofpath (called by ybin) can't work out the correct openfirmware path to the boot partition.  You need to add an ofboot line to your yaboot.conf.  See the PowerPC FAQ question "<nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#I.27ve_lost_yaboot.2C_what_can_I_do.3F|I've lost yaboot what can Ido?]]</nowiki>".  Somehow this can affect the video as well (xorg should be unaffected it is only the openfirmware(?) framebuffer).  Once you run ybin again with the correct ofboot value it should fix itself, but you could also reset the PRAM to correct the video problem.

==== Ubuntu-desktop won't install ====
An update has caused the PowerPC unity package to become out of sync with the unity-common package.  The workaround is described <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showpost.php?p=11483024&postcount=11|here]]</nowiki>.

==== Xorg crashes with radeon UMS ====
If you are runnig kwin or (an old 'stable' version of) compiz you may experience X crashing occasionaly (actually pretty frequently if you resize windows in 'normal' mode).  This is probably caused by the xserver-xorg-core package.  Installing a version before xorg-server-1.10.2-1ubuntu1 seems to fix things although you will have to downgrade/adjust your mesa packages too.  Alternatively, use the patch in comment 40 of <nowiki>[[https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=28181|this]]</nowiki> bug report (see FAQ for compile instructions).

==== Poor colours/distortion with Ubuntu session ====
A few G5 users with nVidia cards (please ammend this if the problem is more widespread) have reported poor colours running the default Ubuntu session.  Try logging out and - if you can see it - at the login screen change to a Ubuntu 2D session. You do this by clicking the cog next to your username. When you log back in you should have correct colours.  If you don't then you need to configure your graphics as per the  <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki>. 

==== nv driver removed from repository ====
If you want to continue to use the nv driver (instead of nouveau) then you'll need to compile it.  Instructions to do so are <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showpost.php?p=11493049&postcount=27|here]]</nowiki>.

=== 11.04 Natty Narwhal ===
==== Poor colours in Unity-2D ====
If you are using the 'Unity' interface in 11.04 and are seeing awful colours, then this is a known problem (https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/unity-2d/+bug/758782|bug) with the unity-2d package and is not a graphics problem. Compile/install a newer version of unity-2d or upgrade to 11.10. The <nowiki>[[http://www.psychocats.net/ubuntu/classicgnome|Classic]]</nowiki> session (which you can select if you log out) is not affected by this problem. 

==== Udev/Udisks bug ====
If you find things are inexplicably slow (or your fan is coming on a lot) then check your CPU usage by running the "top" command from the terminal. The command displays system resources and a list of processes currently being managed by the Linux kernel. If you see "0.0%id" (or a very low number) in the Cpu(s) line then your machine has no spare CPU time. If gvfs-gdu-volume and udisks-daemon are at the top of the processes list then you may be suffering from the <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/udev/+bug/813671|udev/udisks bug]]</nowiki> described in <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1859152|this]]</nowiki> thread. The thread also contains some extra Xubuntu related fixes.

The bug is caused by the Apple cdrom drives not behaving 'normally'.  If you put a CD in the drive you should see a change in the CPU usage.  The bug is fixed in 11.10.

==== Powernowd ====
Powernowd has been removed from 11.04 because somebody deemed it to be redundant. However, it can still be easily installed.  See the <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki>.

==== Lubuntu-desktop won't install ====
In both 10.10 and 11.04 the lubuntu-desktop dependency on the chromium browser has not been removed for PowerPC. Therefore, the lubuntu-desktop meta package will not install.  The workaround is described <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showpost.php?p=11020435&postcount=1|here]]</nowiki>.

==== Notification bubble ====
To change what the notifications bubble looks like in Lubuntu/Xubuntu you can open the terminal and type <code>notification-properties</code>. I suffered from <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/network-manager-applet/+bug/606825|this]]</nowiki> bug so I replaced notification-daemon with notify-osd (used in standard ubuntu). This should be fixed in 11.10.

==== Gnome-mplayer won't install ====
You need to first get and install a package that is missing from 11.04, but is in 10.10.
{{{ 
wget -P/tmp http://ports.ubuntu.com/ubuntu-ports/pool/universe/x/x264/libx264-98_0.98.1653+git88b90d9-3ubuntu2_powerpc.deb
sudo dpkg -i /tmp/libx264-98_0.98.1653+git88b90d9-3ubuntu2_powerpc.deb
}}}
You can then install gnome-mplayer normally.

==== Suspend does not work out-of-the-box with radeon cards ====

See <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/949288|bug]]</nowiki>. It is easy to fix:  

Add radeonfb to the /etc/modules and /etc/initramfs-tools/modules files, following the advice of <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_load_a_kernel_module.3F|this]]</nowiki> question in the <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ]]</nowiki>.  You'll also need to edit your yaboot.conf file to make the video=offb:off <nowiki>[[https://wiki.ubuntu.com/PowerPCFAQ#How_do_I_make_a_yaboot_parameter_permanent.3F|yaboot parameter permanent]]</nowiki>.  

=== 10.04 Lucid Lynx ===
==== CDs / DVDs not recognized ====
If you insert a disk, nothing happens, nothing gets mounted. This problem is known since Karmic (see, e.g. http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1323153 or https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/gnome-mount/+bug/507113). 

You may try the following workaround: 

* Ensure that your /etc/fstab has no entry for your cd/dvd drive.(!)
* Insert a disk into the drive and then issue the following command on the terminal (either as root or per sudo):
 udisks --poll-for-media <your device>

 (where <your device> must be replaced by the appropriate device, e.g., /dev/hdb) and the disk appears as by magic. Eject / unmount then works as expected. You should repeat this command every time after the content of the drive changed (i.e., also after eject) to make it work properly.
* (Optional:) There is a bug report (https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/udisks/+bug/590448) that you can confim. Thanks.
* CD drive related fixes can be found here <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1817971]]</nowiki>.

==== G4 iBook and AlBook fan ====
The command that should make sure you have a working iBook and !AlBook G4 fan in linux is:
<pre>
sudo modprobe therm_adt746x
</pre>
To automate this add <code>therm_adt746x</code> on a new line in the file <code>/etc/modules</code> when you have installed. Future versions of Ubuntu should add <code>therm_adt746x</code> to the list for you, but 10.04 won't. You can check/edit what you have with the command
<pre>
sudo nano /etc/modules
</pre> 
You'll need to reboot before any changes take effect (<code>sudo reboot</code>).

The fan may not work using the alternate CD or mini iso (it is the same when installing Debian).  This is the case with all version up to 12.04 when the therm_adt746x module is built into the kernel.  With versions before 12.04 you could run into overheating issues if you decide to do some CPU intensive thing like shrinking a large partition that's going to take ages! So don't do it! Use a live CD or an existing linux/mac install to do this from where you can easily modprobe the module. 

Using the alternate/mini iso it's obviously a good idea to keep a good level of circulation around the *Book, and if you are cautious (sensible?) then during the base installation only you could maybe setup an external fan to blow on the *Book or maybe sit it on something cool?  It is possible to insmod the module - see the PowerPC FAQ.

==== Hard drive not recognized ====
If you have a 'Blue&White' G3 or a 'Yikes!' G4 machine and during the installation of 10.04 or 10.10 you get a message asking you to select a disk drive driver then you may be suffering from <nowiki>[[https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux/+bug/513131|this]]</nowiki> bug. You may have to start with an install of 8.04 and upgrade to 10.04 or 10.10. The releases 11.04 and 11.10 have the module pata_cmd64x.

==== Busybox shell with LVM ====
See <nowiki>[[http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1898088|this]]</nowiki> thread.

==== Processor Scaling ====
''Note: The <nowiki>[[PowerPCFAQ|PowerPC FAQ]]</nowiki> has alternative instructions to this.''

After the installation there is no cpu frequency scaling. Only the userspace governor works with powerpc CPUs, and, to my experiency only the <code>powernowd</code> package (don't use <code>cpudyn</code> as proposed below). To enable it permanently, perform the following steps.
Edit <code>/etc/init.d/ondemand</code> and replace <code>ondemand</code> by <code>userspace</code>. 
Install the sysfsutils package. Edit <code>/etc/sysfs.conf</code>, and search for the userspace lines to uncomment (or add them to the end). The result should look like: 
<pre>
devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_governor = userspace
devices/system/cpu/cpu0/cpufreq/scaling_setspeed = <your minimal frequency>
</pre>
where <your minimal frequency> should be replaced by a frequecy of your choice determined by
<pre>
sudo cat /sys/devices/system/cpu/*/cpufreq/scaling_available_frequencies 
</pre>
Reboot. You may check for success by adding the CPU Frequency Monitor Applet to your panel.

        VertRefresh     43-117
EndSection

        Identifier      "Default Screen"

        Device          "Configured Video Device"
        DefaultDepth    24
        SubSection "Display"
                Depth 24
                Modes "1024x768" "800x600" "640x480"
        EndSubSection
EndSection
</pre>

=== 9.04 Jaunty Jackalope ===

==== Desktop effects are broken (ATI only) ====

A bug currently prevents desktop effects (DRI) from working properly on PowerPC machines with ATI Radeon video cards.  
As a result, Desktop effects, OpenGL screensavers and any 3D based applications are very slow (about 100 FPs while running glxgears) due to 3D software emulation.

To check, run in a terminal window :
<pre>
lspci | grep VGA
</pre>

You should have something like (depending of your ATI Radeon controller)
<pre>
0000:00:10.0 VGA compatible controller: ATI Technologies Inc Radeon RV250 If [Radeon 9000] (rev 01)
</pre>

Then to benchmark the 3D capabilities, type :
<pre>
glxgears
</pre>
For a Radeon controller between 1000 and 2000 FPs are normal performance.

A workaround is to edit xorg.conf and add the following line to the "Device" section:
<pre>
Option "BusType" "PCI"
</pre>

This workaround can help to reach a decent framerate (about 500 fps for a RV280).

ref: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux-ports/+bug/345542

ref: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1130173

The issue can be definitively solved by upgrading the linux kernel (about 1250 fps for a RV280). 

ref: http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=1145849

=== 8.04 PowerPc alternate install ===

==== Formatting of new partitions fails ====

After creating partitions for / /home swap and a extra data Partition /data and a new world partition for yaboot the installation stops with the following error:

"failed to remove conflicting files.
The installer needs to remove operating system files from the install target, but was unable to do so. The install cannot continue"

Here is the solution:

The problem was, that the advice of the installer programme for the last partition was to mount it on /usr.
When I choose to use it as new world partition, the choice for choosing a mountpoint disappears.
This should be ok, but there seems to be a bug, because the installer still thinks that this partition should be mounted on /usr and then gives the error message above, because it thinks it can't remove operating system files from /usr.

This problem can easily be resolved, if you first choose "don't use" for the partition overwriting the /usr option and second choose to use the partition as new world partition.

=== 8.04 PowerPC LiveCd will not boot on iBookG4 ===
Hold down 'c' to boot the cd. At the livecd prompt (which is yaboot), type the following

 live-nosplash-powerpc modprobe ide-core video=radeonfb:1024x768-24@60

=== 8.04 PowerPC brightness buttons on iBookG4 12" ===

There is a problem with the fn+F1 and fn+F2 buttons regulating the display brightness. An easy way to work around this problem is to make some changes at the yaboot.conf file.

Open the file with an editor:
<pre>
sudo gedit /etc/yaboot.conf
</pre>

find and replace the following:
<pre>
image=/boot/vmlinux
	label=Linux
	read-only
	initrd=/boot/initrd.img
	append="nosplash video=radeonfb:1024x768-24@60"

image=/boot/vmlinux.old
	label=old
	read-only
	initrd=/boot/initrd.img.old
	append="nosplash video=radeonfb:1024x768-24@60"
</pre>

make your changes permanent:
<pre>
sudo ybin -v -C /etc/yaboot.conf
</pre>

and now the fn+F1 and the fn+F2 buttons should work.

For longer instructions, also see forum thread http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=814844

==== Gutsy CDs will not boot ====
You of course hold down 'c' to boot from the cd. At the livecd prompt (yaboot), press tab to see the list of bootable kernels. We recommend trying

<pre>

==== If it stops at busybox shell ====

This happens because the ide module needed to read the root filesystem does not get loaded. At the busybox (intramfs) prompt type

<pre>
modprobe ide-core
exit
</pre>

Booting should then continue. If this does not help, restart and try adding

<pre>
break=top
</pre>

to the earlier boot string. You can do this at yaboot, by typing

<pre>
live break=top
</pre>

Replace live by the kernel you wish to boot. For the earlier command, it would be

<pre>
live-nosplash-powerpc video=ofonly break=top
</pre>

Once you have installed add the line

<pre>
ide-core
</pre>

to /etc/initramfs-tools/modules and run

<pre>
sudo update-initramfs -u
</pre>

==== Sound problems ====

There is a kernel bug that causes processes play sounds to hang. When Gnome plays its startup sound it hangs. You may hear the first fraction of a second of the sound.

Press CTRL+ALT+F1. Log in at the text terminal, if needed. Type

<pre>
killall esd
</pre>

and press enter. Press CTRL+ALT+F7 to return to the desktop. Go to Gnome's Sound Prefs and uncheck the 'ESD' box, this will allow stop the hang in future log ins.

ref: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/linux-source-2.6.22/+bug/87652

==== Blank screen on iMac G3 ====

Do you get a blank screen after booting? The problem is that xorg.conf is not set up properly for the iMac G3.

Follow these steps to fix xorg.conf:

After booting is complete:

 1. Type: '''ctrl-option-F1''' (should give you a command prompt, may take a couple of tries)
 2. Type: '''sudo nano /etc/X11/xorg.conf''' (return)
 3. In the Monitor section, change "Horiz``Sync" to 58-62 and "Vert``Refresh" to 75-117.
 4. Disable DRI. In the Module section, put a hash mark (#) at the beginning of the line containing "load dri". If you have no Module section, make one like this:<pre>
Section "Module"
   Disable "glx"
   Disable "dri"
EndSection
</pre>
 5. Type: '''ctrl-O''' (return) to write edited file
 6. Type: '''ctrl-X''' to exit nano back to command line
 7. Type: '''sudo /etc/init.d/gdm restart''' (return) to restart Gnome. (In Dapper and Edgy, the restart command is broken. Use '''sudo killall -HUP gdm''' instead.)

For longer instructions, also see forum thread http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=405934

==== Wont suspend when you close the lid ====

There is some problem with gnome-power-manager on PowerPC. One way around is to use pbbuttons instead. make sure pbbuttonsd is installed. Then disable gnome-power-manager from starting. This can be done in System->Preferences->Sessions. If this is not effective you may need to remove gnome-power-manager.  If you remove the gnome-power-manager be careful not to remove the gnome-session as well.  Without it, GNOME does not work.  If you accidentally remove it: reboot and at the login screen, press Ctrl-Alt-F1; login and type:

<pre>
  sudo apt-get install gnome-session
</pre>

If your system appears to suspend and resume, but only brings you back to a frozen screen, then it may be due to bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+bug/144305 . To work around this create the following file at /etc/power/event.d/vt_switch
<pre>
case "$1" in
  suspend)
	fgconsole > /tmp/saved-fg-console
	chvt 12
    ;;
  resume)
	CONSOLE=`cat /tmp/saved-fg-console`
	rm /tmp/saved-fg-console
	chvt $CONSOLE
    ;;
esac
</pre>
and make sure it is executable
<pre>
sudo chmod +x /etc/power/event.d/vt_switch
</pre>
